title: Black cleaver and how it effects top laners
body:
Wouldn't it be simpler to not allow ranged champions to use black cleaver than nerfing it into the ground and completely hurting champions like darius garen riven and the like? And if so could we ever see the nerfed changes reverted and just making cleaver melee only like tiamat. {{champion:122}} 

Edit: And also couldnt we just rework darius as its very unfun to be slowed into the past and kited, i understand thats his weakness but i'd rather have less tankyness on darius but more mobility. -- Theres no planned cleavers nerfs right now im talking about old nerfs, secondly the only champions i see Affecting this nerf reset and making cleaver melee only is the champions that shouldnt be using it in the first place IMO.

imo if they want to buff the item again, id rather they slap 100 more health on it and increase the price a tad.

buffs like these always seem to favour melee champs more than ranged, who hate investing more gold into health over ad or the armor shred.
The armor pen nerf was because of the change to armor items, making is just to keep it in check.

Not to mention that the synergy between Urgot and Black Cleaver is so good, it feels like they were designing him around it.

Gets movement speed for passive procs, easy shred stacking with W and he gets health + AD, 2 stats he absolutely loves.

Making Black Cleaver melee only should never happen, it would hurt him way too much.
How many adcs are actually using cleaver? atm I can only think of 1 and thats {{champion:21}} .

English is not my native language.

I would ask all native english speakers for what reason "affect" and "effect" are confused so often..... it is a very curious phenomenon as someone that never took a single formal  english class.
Their pronunciation, spelling and meaning are rather similar.

I mean.... without meaning to sound rude , I assume they teach conjungation in U.S. schools.... right...? I legitimately don't know, as I said I have never taken a single formal english class in my life, I learned english from watching TV and reading Nintendo booklets in the 80s as a young child.

In Mexico, we don't have a particularly stellar education system (to say the least) when it comes to foreign language or history.

> [{quoted}](name=TyrekGoldenspear,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=VAAQ1eqh,comment-id=000500000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-08-01T23:05:03.635+0000)

I honestly would have never guessed.

> I'm actually half-hispanic

Cool.

>As I understand, you prefer to speak English.

Yes.  I was kind of filibustering.... I was referring to my childhood and how it's not fault I was a child prodigy that learned things nearly automatically; I literally learned to play the piano by watching someone do it ONCE.... my mother bought me a keyboard and I kept learning tunes by ear, harder and harder each time because I got bored as soon as I mastered one. I consider myself a complete retard compared to what I used to be, I was legit a child prodigy.... but being in an environment of stupidity (In Mexico, intelligence is considered bad) where everyone is complacent sapped my spirit and I became complacent too.... I wish I had the instinct, the drive I used to have to learn anything and everything as aggressively as possible (My initiative was unparalleled; No one WANTED to learn things as badly/as quickly as I did).

Anyway kind of a funny story (At least to me), whenever I went to school, or my mother made me do chores, or I was forced to attend some family function it was always necessary to speak spanish, I was doing this by force (I.e. "Because I must") and in my free time, doing "fun things" was always  in english (Playing video games, reading booklets, watching TV).

So in a very strange way, it's like my mind was programmed to associate "Fun" with english and "unfun" with spanish. In real life I'm considered INCREDIBLY stoic and serious (Never laugh) but as soon as I start to speak in english my mannerisms, tone, inflections and even facial expressions soften a lot.

I have skimmed a couple of neurological studies that indicate that switching language does in fact change a person's behavior, mannerisms and all of that stuff I mentioned... in my case **I accidentally "wired my brain" to make me super personable and "Charming" (It doesn't come across over the internet) when I am speaking english but super serious and stoic in spanish.**

As I am a university professor, I come across as a real hard-ass (so to speak) except to my english speaking students who all describe me as very weird but super nice and funny.

Etc. I love english, I hate spanish. 
Spanish super rigid. English super flexible.

They are similar enough that I could plausibly see people confusing them in conversation.  Depending on the speaker's accent, it might be difficult for some people to differentiate "affect" and "effect".

Context and sentence structure should be sufficient to determine which word is being used but it might not be apparent unless you already knew the difference between them and their proper usage.

As I'm Canadian, I cannot speak on the state of the education system within the United States.

I forgot about accents. Yeah I see it now. Good point..... the only accent I ever run into is the typical "Normal" U.S. accent (Think California). I had a girlfriend that was from Galveston and I liked... no, absolutely **adored** the way she talked. It was so fucking cute, my god. She was a very attractive woman but even if she was butt fugly, just the cute way of talking would have made me feel super attracted to her.

I would love to learn more about U.S. accents and dialects but it's very difficult from where I am in Mexico.... my favorite of course is the Texas accent but I also like the slight mid-western drawl.  I have a niece that has a "southern belle" accent despite having grown up in Folson California (WTF? I have no idea either) and her manner of speaking is cute as hell.

Also I recently met a woman from "Oregon" which I only discovered was pronounced "Organ" yesterday, and she talked with a strange accent I couldn't quite place.... I was fascinated by the way she spoke. She was about 10 years older than me and only average looks, but I say without shame, I found her incredibly attractive just on the basis of her mysterious accent.

I love english and I love learning more about accents...... damn it Ariel-kun, why don't you have an exotic accent?

I have a very slight "foreigner" accent, but I've been told I sound "european" or "Iraqi" (WTF?)..... when I listen to myself after recording my voice, I don't detect it but I guess that's normal for everyone.
